Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Sunshine Study Plot

Pit shows that depth hoar exists at the upper elevations of the treeline zone. While only 5cm thick, it is still the layer of greatest concern and keeps us suspect of steep slopes in this zone. The slab above it is dense and cohesive in this more exposed below treeline location.

Collapsing, localized; Cracking; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Looks too good to be true! Which it was.. Found much shallower and weaker snow 100' vertical higher, and turned around- slab over depth hoar, which would crack easily the length of your skis. Lots of rime from the last 48 hours above 9500' also.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, widespread; Recent activity on similar slopes
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Approaching the site we had a collapse on the surface hoar, but an added large load would cause the facets over the pencil crust to become the problem layer.
20191203, 15:50, D1 - R4 - WL - AR, recorrido 100 m, altura 980 msnm.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Collapsing, widespread; Recent activity on similar slopes; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: low angle run. would not ski steeper terrain. Similar aspect and elevation but steeper, reactive to explosives

The 0-11 facet layer is thought to be from early season snow from November at this location. Most of this snow has been destroyed by multiple NE wind events and warming. In isolated below treeline areas this layer exists, but is very thin and not thought to be a future problem.

User.name: Steve Reynaud
User.affil: Tahoe National Forest Sierra Avalanche Center

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Structure and stability tests indicate fair stability and confirm the pattern that east aspects near and above treeline have weak snow near the ground. This location however does not have depth hoar. They are just advanced facets and they are showing signs of rounding. 10cm of 1-2 mm rounding facets is encouraging for future stability.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Crown profile from large explosive-triggered avalanche at Jackson Hole Mountain Resort. AE-SS-R2-D2.5-I. Crown depths ranged from 70cm-90cm.
Some basal facets were visible in parts of the profile walls, but too isolated to include in this diagram. Snowpack tests targeted these areas, but did not produce any results.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Maa kivirakkaa. Vieressä kulki kapea tuiskulumen täyttämä uoma (HS 80-90), jossa tuiskulumilaatta irtosi ECTV tuloksella 50 ja 60 cm syvältä. Korppu välissä.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Unknown to me, a group lower on the slope triggered an avalanche while I was digging my pit. This snowpack is very spicey as the snow grains are stronger in compression than sheer, causing slopes with ski tracks to avalanche. I am sure groups before me had a collapse in the area where I dug. There have now been 2 avalanches on this slope and it has been heavily skied before and after the most recent slab was added.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Layer 0cm to 30cm had been previously bootpacked. Half the pit wall was fist facets, and the other half was pencil grains.

User.name: Steve Reynaud
User.affil: Tahoe National Forest Sierra Avalanche Center

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, widespread; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Heard and felt over a dozen large whumpfs. Dug a couple other pits on a more protected NNW slope BTL @ 9,800ft and got some exciting results: HS105cm, ECTP2 and CT0 sudden planar failing simultaneously on a layer of 1-2mm facets @ 55cm from surface and a layer of well preserved 1cm surface hoar @ 40cm from the surface.

Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Recent activity on similar slopes
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Suspect test slope failed after I removed one ski and boot penetrated to ground. Large collapse propagated entire slope back onto 20 deg slope at ridgeline. Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Recent activity on different slopes
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Annual Thanksgiving Pit in standard location at top of KB Ridge - far skier's left of the bowl. Not much slab development, but we did learn that the far skier's right side of the same bowl was skier triggered several hours later. Several collapses on approach and uptrack. Average snowdepth was 90cm, but range was 80-110cm. Much more than expected.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: 35cm of new wind blown snow has brought the scales close to tipping. Poor structure prior to the storm has a load that is now waiting for a trigger. Pit location is not loaded as much as ridgeline terrain. Expect human triggered avalanches in terrain over 35 deg.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Sondeo realizado en la canal de San Luis. Durante el recorrido se aprecian numerosas cornisas con orientación sur, y canales de lluvia. Hay nieve continua a partir de 1300 m. y esquiable a partir de 1800m. El espesor que hemos observado a unos 1800 m. esta entre los 70 cm y 200 cm en zonas de acumulación. Se observan y oyen peuqeñas purgas en las zonas con mayor pendiente.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Montagne's (aka 'Texas') Meadow. Localized variable/gusty winds at this elevation forming isolated small sensitive wind slabs from new snow. Obvious ridgetop wind loading. Stability very good on non-wind-loaded slopes, only fair in areas of new windslab development.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Some surface hoar found today- mostly in the lower and mid elevations. The upper elevation terrain/above treeline, was generally wind affected. No collapsing nor cracking experienced today.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Ridge top winds blowing at approx. 25mph and gusting, lots of snow transport. A layer of facets is developing below the large crust layer at 39cm. A bottom layer of facets is also present. Stability was good.

We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Conditions reflect first snow storm of season. Below 3500', snowpack was wet and grabby. Above 3500', dryer loose powder. Numerous small point releases. Observed a major skier initiated sluff on higher S. aspect MicroDot Big wet natural sluff down Martin mine gully released during storm.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is representative of backcountry; Cracking
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: HS unknown-impenetrable ice lens 47cm from surface. Needed ice axe and crampons to access pit location above the top of the High Noon unload. Dry snow throughout pit even with rain at the tail end of storm. Cracking in top of ice lens up to 4cm deep. Similar to cracking one might see in frozen lake. Air temp taken from 2050m DK

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Weekly-ish snowpit by Irene, Grice, Oli. Only results were below uppermost crust, broken between 93-85 layers. Despite lower 'weak' layers between crusts, crusts are keeping snowpack well locked in place.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: HS unknown. Isothermic conditions present 25cm down. Starting to go spring dirunal below 2050m. Above 2050m is still refrozen rime crust with 3-5cm ice forms on surface. Have lost 12cm of snow at Giant weather station 2050m since 2019.09.16-DK

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug in the Remarkables Ski Field, in upper right JJ's. Only seeing test results reach rain crusts when they are isolated on CTs. In general it seems like the rain crusts are still serving to strengthen the snowpack. No results on SH that is still present on top of July 21st rain crust. Would need a very large load to activate these persistent weak layers. Pit dug by Ferg, Mark, and Gabe.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug 10m below ridge line by Fergus, Mark and Gabe
